lass="word-wrap-span">THE lass="word-wrap-span">SURGE in terrorist attacks by white nationalists includes, this year, lass="word-wrap-span">THE massacres in lass="word-wrap-span">Christchurch (51 dead) and El lass="word-wrap-span">Paso (22 dead). lass="word-wrap-span">Often lass="word-wrap-span">THE lass="word-wrap-span">killers lass="word-wrap-span">cite fears of white “replacement” and draw inspiration from olass="word-wrap-span">THEr, similar atrocities, especially Anders Breivik’s slaughter in 2011 of 77 people in lass="word-wrap-span">Oslo and a nearby island. lass="word-wrap-span">But what is white nationalism, and where did it come from?

lass="word-wrap-span">The phenomenon is hard to define because of its lass="word-wrap-span">ideological and lass="word-wrap-span">geographical lass="word-wrap-span">fractiousness. lass="word-wrap-span">Broadly, white nationalists want to achieve an ethno-state of, and for, whites. lass="word-wrap-span">Some do lass="word-wrap-span">Their best to avoid overtly claiming that any race is lass="word-wrap-span">inferior, arguing that each should have its own ethno-state. lass="word-wrap-span">The majority, however, are white supremacists, who also believe that races form a normative lass="word-wrap-span">hierarchy with whiteness at lass="word-wrap-span">The top. lass="word-wrap-span">They demand policies ranging from stricter controls on immigration to wholesale lass="word-wrap-span">ethnic cleansing, or even lass="word-wrap-span">genocide. lass="word-wrap-span">All this is often tied to lass="word-wrap-span">The fear of “white lass="word-wrap-span">genocide”, or white “replacement”, ie, lass="word-wrap-span">The notion that lass="word-wrap-span">The “white race” is being squeezed out of existence through its own low birth rate, miscegenation and more prolific reproduction by non-white people.

lass="word-wrap-span">Modern white nationalism, which has spread across lass="word-wrap-span">The world, first lass="word-wrap-span">emerged in lass="word-wrap-span">America after lass="word-wrap-span">The civil war. lass="word-wrap-span">With lass="word-wrap-span">The end of slavery, states took action to preserve lass="word-wrap-span">The privileged position of lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Protestants of western lass="word-wrap-span">European lass="word-wrap-span">heritage, including “lass="word-wrap-span">Jim lass="word-wrap-span">Crow” laws that lass="word-wrap-span">enforced segregation. lass="word-wrap-span">Olass="word-wrap-span">Thers took to paramilitary violence and lynchings. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">fixation lass="word-wrap-span">With being white grew lass="word-wrap-span">With increased immigration, especially of lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese people, Irish lass="word-wrap-span">Catholics, soulass="word-wrap-span">Thern lass="word-wrap-span">Europeans and Jews. lass="word-wrap-span">New immigration acts were designed to restrict lass="word-wrap-span">The number of lass="word-wrap-span">New arrivals. lass="word-wrap-span">Madison lass="word-wrap-span">Grant’s “lass="word-wrap-span">The Passing of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Great lass="word-wrap-span">Race”, published in 1916, melded nativist sentiment lass="word-wrap-span">With lass="word-wrap-span">eugenics to produce a lass="word-wrap-span">Theory of white supremacy and “lass="word-wrap-span">Race suicide”. lass="word-wrap-span">Adolf lass="word-wrap-span">Hitler reportedly wrote to lass="word-wrap-span">Grant, stating that lass="word-wrap-span">The book was “his bible”.

lass="word-wrap-span">Though lass="word-wrap-span">discredited by the war against lass="word-wrap-span">Nazism and later by the civil-rights struggles of the 1950s and 60s, white nationalism experienced a resurgence towards the end of the 20th century, leading to a number of violent attacks in lass="word-wrap-span">America and lass="word-wrap-span">Europe.

In 1988 David lass="word-wrap-span">Lane wrote “lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">White lass="word-wrap-span">Genocide lass="word-wrap-span">Manifesto”, giving a new name to lass="word-wrap-span">Grant’s lass="word-wrap-span">Theory of “race suicide”. lass="word-wrap-span">This text introduced lass="word-wrap-span">The world to lass="word-wrap-span">White nationalism’s rallying cry: “We must secure lass="word-wrap-span">The existence of our people and a future for lass="word-wrap-span">White children”, a phrase canonised by lass="word-wrap-span">White nationalists as “lass="word-wrap-span">The 14 words”. lass="word-wrap-span">Beyond a core belief in lass="word-wrap-span">White superiority, lass="word-wrap-span">White nationalists vary widely in lass="word-wrap-span">Their views. lass="word-wrap-span">Some share lass="word-wrap-span">The deep suspicion of lass="word-wrap-span">The federal government found in militia groups; lass="word-wrap-span">Some embrace a revisionist history of lass="word-wrap-span">The civil war that glorifies lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Confederacy; lass="word-wrap-span">Some believe in anti-lass="word-wrap-span">Semitic conspiracies about global Jewish control, including lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Theory that an lass="word-wrap-span">internationalist Jewish lass="word-wrap-span">elite is responsible for encouraging immigration. “”lass="word-wrap-span">The Turner Diaries”, a lass="word-wrap-span">White-nationalist dystopic fantasy published in 1978 by William Lulass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">Pierce, told lass="word-wrap-span">The story of an armed lass="word-wrap-span">insurrection against lass="word-wrap-span">The federal government by defenders of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">White race. It influenced both lass="word-wrap-span">Lane and lass="word-wrap-span">Timothy McVeigh, a disenlass="word-wrap-span">chanted army veteran and gun-rights lass="word-wrap-span">enthusiast who carried out lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Oklahoma lass="word-wrap-span">City bombing, killing 168 people in 1995.

lass="word-wrap-span">White nationalism lass="word-wrap-span">evolved rapidly with lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">advent of lass="word-wrap-span">The internet. It has picked up lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">irony-tinged lass="word-wrap-span">discourse of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">darker corners of lass="word-wrap-span">cyberspace to lass="word-wrap-span">couch political views in a humour that never reveals whelass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">The writer is serious or not. lass="word-wrap-span">This allows lass="word-wrap-span">White nationalists to use non-believers, just in it “for lass="word-wrap-span">The lulz [laughs]”, to spread lass="word-wrap-span">Their message to a wider audience. In lass="word-wrap-span">Europe, meanwhile, lass="word-wrap-span">White nationalists agonised about a supposed lass="word-wrap-span">Islamic lass="word-wrap-span">invasion, particularly after 9/11 and lass="word-wrap-span">The rise of global jihadism. In “lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Great lass="word-wrap-span">Replacement”, lass="word-wrap-span">Renaud lass="word-wrap-span">Camus claimed true lass="word-wrap-span">Frenchmen were being supplanted by immigrants from Africa and lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Middle lass="word-wrap-span">East, encouraged by a “replacist” lass="word-wrap-span">elite. lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">White nationalists have lass="word-wrap-span">incorporated lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims into lass="word-wrap-span">Their taxonomy of invading races but remain mostly focused on lass="word-wrap-span">Latinos, blacks and Jews.

lass="word-wrap-span">Donald lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s critics accuse him of being a white nationalist. lass="word-wrap-span">That goes beyond lass="word-wrap-span">The evidence. lass="word-wrap-span">However, his words do play into lass="word-wrap-span">The supremacist lass="word-wrap-span">ideology. lass="word-wrap-span">For example, in 2017 he described a “lass="word-wrap-span">Unite lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Right” march in lass="word-wrap-span">Charlottesville, Virginia, as “people protesting very quietly lass="word-wrap-span">The taking down lass="word-wrap-span">The statue of Robert E. lass="word-wrap-span">Lee”, a surprisingly gentle way of describing self-proclaimed Nazis marching with tiki torches and lass="word-wrap-span">chanting “Jews will not replace us”. lass="word-wrap-span">last year lass="word-wrap-span">Right-wing lass="word-wrap-span">extremists lass="word-wrap-span">killed more people in lass="word-wrap-span">America than in any year since 1995, lass="word-wrap-span">The year of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Oklahoma lass="word-wrap-span">City bombing. lass="word-wrap-span">The vast majority of lass="word-wrap-span">These were by white supremacists. It is a threat lass="word-wrap-span">That authorities in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">West have taken too lightly.
